Problem:
Consider a linear system described by the continuous Fourier transform \\( \\hat{f}(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} f(t) e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\), where \\( f(t) \\) is a time-domain signal. We analyze the impact of a modulation defined by the function \\( g(t) = e^{i\\alpha t} \\) over time t, where \\( \\alpha \\) is a real constant.

Given the frequency spectrum \\( \\hat{f}'(\\omega) \\), can we deduce the original signal \\( f(t) \\) without knowing whether modulation \\( g(t) \\) was applied?
Explanation: Without knowing whether and what type of modulation was applied, it's not possible to correctly deduce \\( f(t) \\) from \\( \\hat{f}'(\\omega) \\) alone, as the shift in frequency could misrepresent the original frequency components of \\( f(t) \\).

causal_map_integration: The original time-domain signal f(t) causes the Fourier transform \\hat{f}(\\omega). The modulation function g(t) causes changes in the frequency spectrum \\hat{f}'(\\omega) and also influences the original signal f(t). The Fourier transform \\hat{f}(\\omega) leads to the modified frequency spectrum \\hat{f}'(\\omega), which in turn can lead back to the original signal f(t).
